text: I slowly move my hand toward my short sword, but I don’t expect the scabbard at my waist to lightly clash with a clear ‘clang.’
The drunk whirls around, bloodshot eyes glaring at me.
“What are you trying to do?!”
His anger ignites at once, his fist slamming heavily onto the table, wine splashing everywhere.
“You dare draw your sword?!”
I instinctively take a step back. My hand hasn’t fully gripped the hilt yet, but the air is already thick with tension.
Just as he takes that step forward, a sharp sound cuts through the air—
Alicia is already on her feet, her cloak sweeping past the hearth as a flash of silver light flickers.
No one sees what she does. In the next instant, the drunk is pinned to the ground, his face buried in his own spilled wine.
I stare at her in a daze. At that moment, I finally realize—I never needed to draw my sword at all.
She withdraws her blade, the firelight glinting faintly along the fractured patterns etched into the steel.
“You were a step too slow.”
“Looks like you didn’t need any help either.”
Alicia lifts her gaze slightly. The firelight flickers in her pupils, as if she’s smiling—or perhaps not.
“Perhaps.”
She slowly sheaths her sword, the metal brushing softly against the scabbard.
The air begins to move again. The hearth crackles, and a few patrons peek out before retreating back to their seats.
“Clean this up. No need to attract the guards and invite trouble.”
Her voice carries no command—only a calm statement.
“Alright.”
I nod and pick up a cloth to wipe the spilled wine from the table. She stands quietly nearby, as if waiting for me—or perhaps lost in thought.
